title: Former Burnley midfielder Lenny Johnrose calls for heading ban for under-14s after landmark new research
text:
Lenny Johnrose, the former Blackburn Rovers, Bury and Burnley midfielder who is now living with motor neurone disease, has called on football to implement a heading ban for Under-14s in an attempt to minimise risks for children.

Landmark research this week by the University of Glasgow focused on former professional players and could not define the precise cause of a significantly heightened likelihood of brain disease, but there was found to be a four-fold increase in those who died of motor neurone disease and a five-fold rise in Alzheimer’s.

This reinforces research which has suggested that head trauma is associated with a range of neurological diseases and Johnrose believes that global football should now follow the United States in adopting a precautionary approach for children.

“At least in America they have done something straight away,” he said. “We're taking chances with people's lives and it does sicken me. I don't see the point in taking that risk. It's not even a big loss, to say: 'At your age, 14 and under, you're not heading the ball'. It won't cause any harm or damage to anybody.”

The Football Association does not currently believe that there is sufficient evidence to make any change to children’s football and has instead reissued guidance on concussion management and limiting heading practice. They also emphasised the wider health benefits of playing football and being active, with the Glasgow study also showing improved heart and lung health, as well as a three-year longer life expectancy.
